title: Battle - hardened Spain ready for Women World Cup final
body_text:
Spain coach Jorge Vilda says Australia and England are the two toughest opponents his side could have faced in the Women's World Cup final, insisting he has no preference for who reaches Sunday's decider.

La Roja won through to the first major women's tournament final in the country's history on Tuesday night, dispatching Sweden with a late show in Auckland.
In a frenzied nine final minutes of regular time, teenage star Salma Paralluelo and captain Olga Carmona scored goals either side of Rebecka Blomqvist's equaliser for a 2-1 win.
"This is something that is fabulous for Spanish football," Vilda said shortly after the match.
"If you go to the dressing room it's incredible how they're celebrating.
"We're going to Sydney tomorrow and we want to win."
The victory franks Spain's rise from a run-of-the-mill nation to a powerhouse in the women's game.
It was not until 2015 that they qualified for a World Cup, until 2021 they were ranked inside the top 10, and until this month they'd won a knockout match at major tournament.
Spain have also endured a trying month in New Zealand, sparking controversy and offering apologies when their players imitated the haka, the treasured Maori dance, causing offence to Kiwis.
They left their training base in Palmerston North due to boredom, were thrashed 4-0 by Japan in their final group game, and were even rattled by two earthquakes during their time in Wellington.
Before that there was a player mutiny last year which resulted in 12 players boycotting this tournament, including defender Mapi Leon, goalkeeper Sandra Panos and midfielder Patricia Guijarro, a trio of Champions League winners at Barcelona.
As he has done all month, Vilda stonewalled a question in his post-match press conference on how that had affected the team, pointing to his support from the federation to continue as coach.
"I value my players a lot," he said.
"And in the end result, it's a learning process which has made us all stronger in my opinion.
"(I will) leave the archives in the past, to think about the future ... we deployed all energy into what's positive."
In their place a new bunch of stars are emerging, including Paralluelo.
The 19-year-old has spent just one full season in senior football after ending a promising sprinting career, and has now scored an extra-time winner in Spain's quarter-final and the opener in Tuesday's semi-final.
Goalkeeper Cata Coll is another who is flourishing despite being Panos's understudy at Barcelona.
The 22-year-old won her first cap for Spain in the round-of-16 win over Switzerland and has held her place since, with Vilda heralding her training performances as "extraordinary".
The challenge now for Spain is either the Matildas, riding high on the support of a nation, or the Lionesses, who defeated them en route to their European Championship title last year.
Vilda said both semi-finalists were "extremely competitive" with "extremely good" coaches.
"They're the two best teams that could have reached the semi-final and they're there through merit," he said.
"We are going to be very attentive to what happens."
Australian Associated Press
